QLSTATUS(1) ql-status Manual QLSTATUS(1)

NAME

qlstatus - a light and modular status bar

SYNOPSIS

qlstatus [-h] [-v] [-c file]

DESCRIPTION

qlstatus is a small program with minimalistic and modular approach for generating a status bar for tiling window managers like dwm(1) or spectrwm(1).

When qlstatus starts up, it reads settings from its configuration file, qlstatus.conf. See the section CONFIGURATION below.

OPTIONS

-h, --help
Print usage statement.

-v, --version

Print version and exit.

-c, --config <file>

Load settings from specified configuration file.

CONFIGURATION

qlstatus looks for user-configuration file in the following order:

(1) file specified through --config option
(2) ~/.config/qlstatus.conf

If user-configuration file is not found, it looks for system-configuration file in ~/etc/qlstatus.conf. If no configuration file is found, qlstatus then is configured with default settings.

Format of the configuration file is a list of settings of the form:

keyword = setting

Comment lines begin with a ‘#’. For inline comments, ‘#’ must be preceded by a white space or a tab.

qlstatus allows you to enable and choose which “modules” to display through the global format option. Each module is composed of “tokens” which may be or not displayed through the format option of the corresponding module. Configure global and module outputs by specifying desired format strings. See options below.

global options

format
Specify global output format. It may contain the following character sequences to enable and display desired modules. Any other character will be print.


%D date and time
%U CPU usage
%F CPU frequency
%T temperature
%M memory usage
%L brightness level
%V audio volume
%B battery level and status
%W wireless SSID and signal strength

All modules are enabled by default.

rate
Specify refresh rate of the output in seconds or milliseconds. Must match pattern [n]s or [n]ms.

Default: 1s

enable_spectrwm_colors
Enable or disable the support of spectrwm colors. Should be enable only with spectrwm as window manager. Must be 0 or 1.

Default: 0

critical_color_index
Specify index of spectrwm color to use for display modules in critical state. Must be a number in range 0 to 9.

Default: 1

date and time

time_format
Specify date and time format. Must match strftime(3) format specification.

Default: %a %d %b %Y, %R %Z

battery level

battery_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L current status
%V battery level in percent

Default: %L %V

battery_name
Specify battery name. Must match pattern BAT[n].

Default: BAT0

battery_full_design
Enable or disable battery full design. When enabled, gives the real battery level taking into account its wear. Must be 0 or 1.

Default: 1

battery_label_full
Specify label to display when battery is fully charged.

Default: full

battery_label_charging
Specify label to display when battery is charging.

Default: chr

battery_label_discharging
Specify label to display when battery is discharging.

Default: bat

battery_label_unknown
Specify label to display when current battery status is unknown.

Default: unk

battery_critical
Specify critical battery level in percent.

Default: 20

power notifications

power_notifications
Enable or disable power notifications related to battery events. Must be 0 or 1.

Default: 1

power_notify_icon_full
Specify icon name or icon path to use in notification triggered when battery is fully charged.

Default: battery-full-charged

power_notify_icon_plugged
Specify icon name or icon path to use in notification triggered when AC adapter is plugged.

Default: ac-adapter

power_notify_icon_low
Specify icon name or icon path to use in notification triggered when battery reach the critical level.

Default: battery-caution

CPU usage

cpu_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%V CPU usage in percent

Default: %L %V

cpu_label
Specify the module label.

Default: cpu

cpu_critical
Specify critical CPU usage threshold in percent.

Default: 80

CPU frequency

cpu_freq_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%V CPU frequency
%U unit

Default: %L %V%U

cpu_freq_label
Specify the module label.

Default: freq

cpu_freq_unit
Specify the frequency unit. Must be KHz, MHz, GHz or smart. smart automatically scales frequency value to the shortest three digit unit.

Default: MHz

cpu_freq_scaling
If enabled, qlstatus looks for read scaling attributes to compute current CPU frequency. Some scaling drivers (e.g. intel_pstate) attempt to provide information more precisely reflecting the current CPU frequency through these attributes. Must be 0 or 1.

Default: 1

temperature

temperature_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%V temperature in degree Celsius

Default: %L %V

temperature_label
Specify the module label.

Default: temp

temperature_dir
Specify path for temperature attributes directory. May contain an asterisk ‘*’ to resolve last directory of the path. If an asterisk is present then first directory found is chosen.

Default: /sys/devices/platform/coretemp.0/hwmon/*

temperature_input
Specify an attribute number or a range to compute a temperature average. qlstatus looks for attribute filenames that match pattern temp[r]_input where r is the specified value. Value must match pattern [n] for specific attribute file or [n]-[n] for a range of attribute files.

Default: 2-5

temperature_critical
Specify critical temperature in degree Celsius.

Default: 80

memory usage

memory_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%C used memory
%T total available memory
%U unit
%P used memory in percent

Default: %L %C/%T%U (%P)

memory_label
Specify the module label.

Default: mem

memory_unit
Specify the memory unit. Must be KiB, MiB, GiB or smart. smart automatically scales used and total memory value to the shortest three digit unit.

Default: MiB

memory_critical
Specify critical memory usage threshold in percent.

Default: 80

brightness level

brightness_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%V brightness level in percent

Default: %L %V

brightness_label
Specify the module label.

Default: brg

brightness_dir
Specify path for backlight attributes directory. Should not be changed.

Default: /sys/class/backlight/intel_backlight

audio volume

volume_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L label
%V volume level in percent

Default: %L %V

volume_label
Specify the module label.

Default: vol

volume_muted_label
Specify the label when audio is muted.

Default: mut

volume_sink_name
Specify sink name. See pactl(1) for how to get information about sinks.

Default: alsa_output.pci-0000_00_1f.3.analog-stereo

wireless SSID and signal

wireless_format
Specify module format. It may contain the following character sequences:


%L current SSID
%V signal strength in percent

Default: %L: %V

wireless_unknown_label
Specify the label when SSID is unknown.

Default: SSID unk

wireless_interface
Specify name of wireless interface.

Default: wlan0

INTEGRATION IN DWM

dwm reads the name of the root window and redirects it to its statusbar area. The root window is the root of the window tree handled by the window manager. Like any other window, the root window has a name, but it is usually undefined because the root window always runs in the background.

You can compile following C program to redirect qlstatus output as the name of the root window:

#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <X11/Xlib.h>
int             main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    Display     *dpy = NULL;
    Window      win = 0;
    size_t      length = 0;
    ssize_t     bytes_read = 0;
    char        *input = NULL;
    dpy = XOpenDisplay(getenv("DISPLAY"));
    if (dpy == NULL) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Can't open display, exiting.\n");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    win = DefaultRootWindow(dpy);
    while ((bytes_read = getline(&input, &length, stdin)) != EOF) {
        input[strlen(input) - 1] = 0;
        XStoreName(dpy, win, input);
        XFlush(dpy);
    }
    free(input);
    return 0;
}

Save this code in dwm-setstatus.c and compile it:

gcc dwm-setstatus.c -lX11 -o dwm-setstatus

Finally, move or add dwm-setstatus binary to your $PATH. To use qlstatus as dwm statusbar, you can for example add into ~/.xinitrc:

...
(qlstatus | dwm-setstatus) &
exec dwm

INTEGRATION IN SPECTRWM

Specify qlstatus as external script through the option bar_action in your spectrwm configuration file: 

bar_action = qlstatus

That's it.

FILES

/etc/qlstatus.conf
/usr/local/bin/qlstatus
/usr/local/share/man/man1/qlstatus.1

NOTES

The support of spectrwm colors is stopped for now.

BUGS

In case of bug, please open an issue on GitHub repository page.

SEE ALSO

dwm(1), spectrwm(1)

AUTHORS
